column1: text

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “Longtime American expatriates here like to recall what happened in the 1970s when Japan easily absorbed the same heavy body blows from the organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries that bring other developed nations to their knees ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Japan had strong economy, efficient production, and innovative technology to withstand external shocks.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “New Pig Corp . , Tipton , Pa . , offers a hot - dog - shaped sponge that absorbs polluting liquids around factory machines ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:To describe the specific function and purpose of the sponge in absorbing liquids to prevent pollution.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “Most of these losses must be absorbed by the FSLIC , the industry 's insurer , analysts said ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:The FSLIC is responsible for covering losses in the industry as its insurer.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “To expect banks to absorb a cost without a commensurate charge defies logic ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Banks are expected to cover the cost without passing it on to customers.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “Districts jump back and forth over mountain ranges , cross large bodies of water , send out little tentacles to absorb special communities and ensure safe seats . '”?
Usage:literal
Reason:"Absorb" is used literally to describe districts expanding and incorporating new areas for political advantage.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “He added : '' There is so much space out there that people are making deals at good prices , absorbing space ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:It refers to the physical act of taking in or occupying available space.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “-- Futures dealers on the floors of the various exchanges '' absorbed some selling pressure '' but they were n't '' able to counterbalance the public selling pressure . '”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Futures dealers were able to handle some selling pressure, but not enough to counterbalance public selling.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “With its strength in the Old South , the Rocky Mountain and northern plains states and such dependable GOP bastions as Indiana , the party can absorb some losses and still accumulate close to 200 electoral votes ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Diverse support base can withstand losses and still secure significant electoral votes.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “Mr. Filisko says his fluids do n't rely on absorbed water , and perform better as temperatures rise ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:The fluids do not rely on absorbing water for performance and function better in higher temperatures.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “The fatty deposits have a yellowish hue and therefore absorb more of the yellow laser energy than the surrounding , almost colorless artery wall ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:The fatty deposits have a higher concentration of yellow pigments, leading to increased absorption.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “In spite of her wifely obligations -LRB- which ceased upon her official separation from Teddy in 1911 , followed by divorce -RRB- , her wealth and social standing allowed her to go where she pleased , read what she liked , and enjoy all she could absorb of a world that seemed to her to overflow with richness and beauty ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Her wealth and social standing allowed her to access and fully engage with her surroundings.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “But Korea 's booming economy can absorb them , economists say ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:- Strong economy can create jobs and opportunities for incoming workers.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “The court ruled , however , that the trust will now have to absorb more of that cost ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Trust is financially responsible for the cost and must bear the financial burden.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “Burt Sugarman , chairman of the cement company , said third - quarter earnings were hurt by unrealized losses on stocks in its investment portfolio of about $ 2 million , and by having to absorb about $ 3.9 million of a $ 6.9 million net loss recently posted by Barris Industries Inc. with no associated tax benefits ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Financial responsibility and obligation to cover losses incurred by Barris Industries Inc.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “'' The market is absorbing all of the mill 's output of supercalender paper , '' Mr. Nugent said ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:The market is physically taking in or utilizing all of the mill's output.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “But he said Cigna 's after - tax gain wo n't be material because the company will absorb certain deferred taxes of the division ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Cigna can offset the gain with deferred taxes from the division.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “With its large stock of sober , muscular buildings , Chicago has been able to absorb Mr. Jahn 's work ; there , Xerox Centre 's sweeping curve of white metal and reflective glass , or One South Wacker 's long grids of pale pink and pale blue glass can seem like light relief . -LRB- For similar reasons , his recent Chryslerlike blue - glass tower can be accommodated in downtown Philadelphia -RRB- ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Chicago's architecture complements and integrates Mr. Jahn's work, allowing it to blend in harmoniously.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “The Monitor 's losses are absorbed by the church 's working fund , which reportedly has declined during the past two years to about $ 200 million from more than $ 280 million , largely because of the stock - market crash ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Stock market crash caused decline in church's working fund, absorbing losses from The Monitor.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “'' We 're talking about $ 50 billion to $ 60 billion of debt that the taxpayer will have to absorb , '' Emory University 's Mr. Benston says ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Debt will directly impact taxpayers financially, as they will be responsible for paying it back.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “-- The peaceful absorption into the world economy and polity of nations now moving swiftly to absorb all the major technologies , a group including among others , China and India , Brazil and Mexico ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:It refers to the integration of countries into the global economy and political system.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “Equally important , his Socialist government absorbed and then , in effect , destroyed the French Communist Party ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:To eliminate competition and consolidate power.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “In no case did expenditures rise enough after the war to absorb the revenue that would have been available if the war taxes had been retained ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Government spending did not increase enough to use up the revenue from war taxes.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “But he said Cigna 's after - tax gain wo n't be material because the company will absorb certain deferred taxes of the division ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Cigna will offset the gain by using deferred taxes from the division.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “An early new accord would absorb the existing one ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:"absorb" is used non-metaphorically because it means to take in or incorporate something.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “The plan calls for Ferruzzi Finanziaria , the family holding company that controls the Ferruzzi - Montedison group and is now closely held , to absorb Iniziativa Me . T.A. unit in a stock swap ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:To consolidate operations and streamline management within the Ferruzzi - Montedison group.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “He said that MMWEC will have to absorb only $ 4 million in additional annual costs now paid by the Vermont utilities ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:literal financial burden transferred from Vermont utilities to MMWEC.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “Mr. Thunberg of Ried Thunberg said the Fed has '' aggressively '' absorbed reserves over each of the past three days , creating some confusion about its intentions ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:To describe the Federal Reserve's actions of taking in or removing excess reserves from the market.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “Nearly four - fifths of this increase would be absorbed by the rising cost of Social Security benefits and the cost of keeping outlays for defense and education even with inflation , as Mr. Bush has proposed ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Increasing costs of Social Security, defense, and education will use up most of the increase.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “This cost has been absorbed by me in the hope that the FDA would reward my efforts with its favor ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:To cover or bear the cost without passing it on to others or seeking reimbursement.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “As a result , total investment from all sources , domestic and foreign , of about 16 % of gross national product is still way short of the 25 % analysts believe is needed to absorb a fast - expanding labor force ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Increased investment needed to create job opportunities and support economic growth for expanding labor force.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “'' It is actually easier for this market to absorb small increases for the yen -LRB- against the dollar -RRB- , '' Mr. Nakaharu said , '' although of course a sudden fall for the dollar would be a problem . '”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Market is able to handle small increases in yen due to stability and gradual adjustment.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “An Energy Department spokesman says the sulfur dioxide might be simultaneously recoverable through the use of powdered limestone , which tends to absorb the sulfur ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Limestone chemically reacts with sulfur dioxide to form a compound, physically absorbing the gas.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “GM ca n't continue to absorb indefinitely the large fixed costs represented by unused capacity , he says ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Unused capacity leads to costs without generating revenue, impacting profitability and sustainability of the business.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “The FDIC staff also noted that Wells Fargo would have given the agency no control over the selection and management of bad loans for which the agency would have to absorb all losses ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:- The FDIC would have to take on the financial responsibility for the bad loans.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “At this year 's rate of $ 3.25 billion a month as tracked by IDD , it would take nearly four years for buy - outs to absorb $ 150 billion ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Buy-outs are gradually consuming the $150 billion in funds over a four-year period.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “By 1983 he had become so absorbed in his quest that he resigned as China correspondent for The Wall Street Journal and spent much of the next four years in China visiting relatives , searching libraries and scrabbling through underbrush looking for grave sites ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:He became deeply interested and engrossed in his quest, leading him to resign and focus on it.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “Remics are absorbing the bulk of newly issued mortgage securities as institutional buyers , such as thrifts and insurance companies , prefer the more tailored investment features of structured mortgage securities to the greater payment uncertainties of ordinary pass - throughs issued by Ginnie Mae , Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:Remics offer tailored features and lower payment uncertainties compared to traditional pass-throughs.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “'' In a small company , the CEO and his people become so absorbed in the Eleven that it dominates the existence of the company . '”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:Because they are fully focused and engrossed in the project, to the point of obsession.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “During the past 18 months , the Houston - based unit of Texas Air Corp. absorbed several carriers , in the process inheriting a hodge - podge of different aircraft ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:to acquire their assets and operations, consolidate market share, and expand routes and services.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “Some diamond analysts said dealers may find it difficult to absorb De Beers latest price increase , particularly since it followed a 10 % rise in prices in early October ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:High prices may deter buyers, causing dealers to struggle to manage the increased costs.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “Mr. Ennis said he believes Rockwood got into financial difficulty because its expansion efforts '' outstripped its ability to absorb those activities . '”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:Limited resources, lack of proper planning, rapid growth, inadequate infrastructure.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “While the rest of the nation watched with mere curiosity or slight concern , the nation 's fourth - largest city was thoroughly absorbed by the approach of Hurricane Gilbert ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:Houston residents were focused on preparing and protecting themselves from the impending danger.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “Meanwhile , Democratic nominee Michael Dukakis -- after a month of absorbing Republican blows on his patriotism and being portrayed as a big taxer -- tried to gain the offensive with an old Democratic chestnut : the Republicans are going to take away your Social Security ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:Dukakis used the metaphor of absorbing blows to show resilience and strategy in the election.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “Robert K. Heady , publisher of Bank Rate Monitor , a North Palm Beach , Fla . , interest rate newsletter , said banks '' did n't jump through hoops to raise savings yields 24 hours after absorbing the news of the Federal discount rate . '”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:Banks were not quick to raise savings yields because they had already factored in the news.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “Mr. Wyss of Data Resources suggested that factories may be having difficulty hiring new workers at a time of such low unemployment or may simply not be able to absorb as many new workers as they would like ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:1. Lack of necessary skills
2. Limited physical space
3. Insufficient resources or funding

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “But in the short - term it will absorb a lot of top management 's energy and attention , '' says Philippe Haspeslagh , a business professor at the European management school , Insead , in Paris ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:Because it will require a lot of focus and effort from top management to address.

Is “absorb” used metaphorically in “Jordan , with a flagging economy and a 4.2 % annual birth - rate , could n't absorb another influx of refugees no matter how sympathetically it viewed their plight ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:Limited resources and strain on infrastructure.

Is “assault” used metaphorically in “Mr. Guez , of Old Westbury , N.Y . , also is currently under indictment and awaiting trial for allegedly assaulting a deputy U.S. marshal who tried to seize Sasson records last year at the posh $ 5.5 million Manhattan townhouse where Mr. Guez once resided ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:The assault was a physical attack on a deputy U.S. marshal during a seizure attempt.

Is “assault” used metaphorically in “Among the tantrums he admits : heaving a faulty phone across the control room , kicking in a TV screen to force NBC to buy a new one , and assaulting construction workers who were too noisy during taping ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:The actions described involve physical violence and aggression towards others.

Is “assault” used metaphorically in “He was detained on June 23 , and for two weeks he was regularly assaulted by South African police ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:It describes physical attacks or violence carried out by the South African police.

Is “assault” used metaphorically in “Sound is not the only thing with which the audience is assaulted at '' Chess . '”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:- Overwhelming visuals
- Intense emotions
- Intrusive storytelling
- Chaotic pacing

Is “assault” used metaphorically in “The bill admits that the key to winning the drug war is assaulting the demand side ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:Assault implies aggressive action to combat and reduce drug consumption.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “It is to this purpose that SDI laser technology can be uniquely directed , where moving targets can be attacked almost immediately after they are detected ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:To accurately describe the action of targeting and engaging with hostile objects in a military context.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “He said he intends to push the party to endorse raising the top personal - income - tax rate , perhaps to 38 % from the current 28 % , to attack the federal deficit accumulated during the Reagan years ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:To address economic issues and reduce deficit through increased revenue generation.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “The best of show in painting , Oleg Stavrowsky 's 40-inch by 72-inch oil of a stagecoach being attacked by bandits , went for $ 14 , 000 ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:It describes a physical assault on a stagecoach, not a figurative or symbolic attack.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Labor unions , too , attack the underground economy ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Labor unions actively combat and oppose the illegal activities associated with the underground economy.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “'' We 're going to keep attacking . '”?
Usage:literal
Reason:It is a strategy in sports or warfare to aggressively pursue a goal or objective.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Dukakis plans to attack Gephardt for taking special - interest money ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:It refers to a planned criticism or confrontation, not a physical assault or military action.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “IBP attacked the report as not factual and full of innuendo and as '' egotistical '' grandstanding by the subcommittee chairman , Rep. Tom Lantos -LRB- D . , Calif. -RRB- ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:To describe a strong and aggressive response or criticism towards the report and its author.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “I arrived in Vietnam in early 1968 , as green as the beret I wore , and was assigned to the Special Forces '' A '' team that had the dubious distinction , two weeks later , of being one of the first attacked during the Tet offensive ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:- To describe a physical assault or military engagement.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Here in Masaya , supporters of a group known as the Mothers of Political Prisoners were brutally attacked by turbas in a well - documented incident in March ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:literal violence occurred against the Mothers of Political Prisoners by the turbas in March.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “'' I think glasnost is bad when they attack Stalin . '”?
Usage:literal
Reason:"attack" is used in a literal sense to describe a physical or verbal assault on Stalin.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Indeed , Richard Gephardt , Jesse Jackson and Michael Dukakis have all made public appearances in support of Eastern 's union -- sometimes sharply attacking Mr. Lorenzo ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:They disagree with his actions or decisions regarding Eastern Airlines and its union.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Justice Abrams , so viciously attacked by Mr. Cooper , was earlier a hard - nosed career prosecutor ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:- To describe the aggressive and harsh criticism or confrontation by Mr. Cooper.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “It was one of the congressional spending programs President Reagan attacked in his State of the Union address ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:The word "attacked" is used non-metaphorically because it refers to criticizing or opposing something.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Mr. Bush attacked the Massachusetts governor for vetoing a bill to require school teachers to lead pupils in the pledge of allegiance and for Massachusetts ' prisoner - furlough program ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:To criticize or condemn harshly and publicly.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Tamil militants attacked and set fire to two Moslem fishing villages in eastern Sri Lanka ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Ethnic conflict, retaliation, territorial control, religious tensions, revenge, political motives.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Common Cause has attacked the Ways and Means Committee 's proposal to repeal the $ 3 , 000 limit on the deductibility of congressional living expenses in Washington , D.C ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Common Cause criticized the proposal for repealing the limit on congressional living expenses deductibility.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Iranian gunboats attacked an Indian tanker in the Persian Gulf , setting the vessel ablaze and wounding at least one crew member , gulf - based shipping executives reported ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Because the Iranian gunboats physically targeted and damaged the Indian tanker in the Persian Gulf.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Pull out the big stick , of course , and attack the Democrats ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Literal instruction to physically or verbally confront Democrats with force or aggression.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “From the 14th century to Corregidor in 1942 , such forts had to be taken by storm before attacking ships could pass ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Fortresses provided strategic advantage and needed to be captured before advancing in naval warfare.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “They have agreed to attack only the Socalists , not each other , so Mr. Barre must find a way to beat Mr. Chirac without talking about him ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Maintaining unity against common enemy, avoiding internal conflict, focusing on shared goals and strategies.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Only American policy in Vietnam has been as maligned , vilified and attacked as U.S. policy toward Iran ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Misunderstanding, historical tensions, differing ideologies, perceived threats, geopolitical interests, cultural misunderstandings, religious differences.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Pakistani cheating could prompt Moscow to declare the accords void or to attack Afghan - resistance camps in Pakistan ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:1. National security concerns
2. Retaliation for cheating
3. Defense of interests

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “But international groups that attacked Mr. Jenninger 's remarks may find themselves among the losers ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:The word "attack" is used non-metaphorically because it refers to criticism or opposition.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Already , President - elect Carlos Salinas de Gortari has found himself and his closest advisers attacked by the nation 's two strongest labor leaders : Fidel Velazquez , boss of the Confederation of Mexican Workers -LRB- CTM -RRB- , and oil union chief Joaquin Hernandez Galicia ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Power struggle, threat to influence and control, challenge to authority and policies.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “In Greece , an official said the terrorists who attacked the liner in the Aegean Sea may have been pro - Iranian Arabs trying to hijack it ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:The word "attack" is used non-metaphorically to describe a physical assault on the liner.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Secretary of State George Shultz last week attacked as '' shocking '' Mr. Dukakis 's willingness to recognize Jerusalem rather than Tel Aviv as Israel 's capital -- a move that has been long sought by the Israelis and would be popular with Jewish voters in the U.S . , but that Mr. Shultz asserts would complicate efforts to find a Mideast peace ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Could provoke conflict, stir tensions, threaten peace process, go against international consensus on Jerusalem.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “By spreading the benefits of economic development into depressed regions , Massachusetts economic policy has attacked structural unemployment ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:- To address and reduce structural unemployment in those regions. 
- To stimulate job creation and growth in those areas. 
- To improve overall economic conditions and opportunities.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Major newspapers generally endorse the notion of liberalization , but they are n't attacking the GATT solution ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Newspapers support liberalization but do not criticize the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Because a commitment to hold open the 74.4 miles of supply road to Khost from Gardez would require even more Soviet casualties and force , the optimists surmise that the Soviets are attacking Khost to get out of Afghanistan ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:To avoid further casualties and retreat from Afghanistan.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “The union leaders also will attack one of Wall Street 's most dearly held beliefs about Texas Air -- something that has long helped to sustain its stock price : that for all its losses and labor travails , the company still sits on a motherlode of cash ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:To challenge or dispute Wall Street's belief about Texas Air's financial stability.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “This suggests a panicky response from the Vincennes , particularly since a Pentagon air - combat specialist quoted by Mr. Kaplan in the Boston Globe said that an attacking F-14 probably would be traveling '' at at least 550 to 580 knots , '' 100 knots faster than Adm. Crow says the Airbus was flying , and '' well under 1 , 000 feet . . . ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:- To describe a physical military operation.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Suzy says she almost did n't answer the Revson column : '' But nobody , especially nobody of this ilk , can attack the queen ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Suzy felt intimidated or threatened by the Revson column and its potential consequences.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “In hearings before Mr. Needelman last August , the lawyers attacked the seeming contradictions between the papers ' earlier upbeat statements and ambitious spending , and their more recent statements that the Free Press is failing ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:To criticize or challenge the inconsistencies in the organization's statements and financial performance.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “In northern Nicaragua , Honduran jets attacked a Sandinista military headquarters ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:It describes a physical act of aggression by one country against another.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Prince Norodom Sihanouk , the former Cambodian leader , said this week he was withdrawing from the resistance because the Khmer Rouge continues to attack his forces along the Thai - Cambodia border ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Due to ongoing military aggression and threats to his forces' safety and security.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “An Agence France Press dispatch on August 8 reported that an Afghan air force plane was shot down by a Pakistani F-16 while attacking Afghan refugee camps 30 kilometers inside Pakistan territory , near Miram Shah ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Because it describes a physical military operation that resulted in the shooting down of a plane.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “The administration tried again in mid-1987 , suspending military and economic aid to Panama after rioters , led by some government officials , attacked the American Embassy in Panama City ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Diplomatic breach, breach of international law, violation of sovereignty, threat to American citizens.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “While proposing such cuts to attack the current deficit , Mr. Jackson is vague on how the expensive new social programs he proposes would pay for themselves ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Because it refers to a deliberate and aggressive attempt to reduce the deficit through budget cuts.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “The Bush strategists insist they will not attack Mr. Robertson , noting that much of their own support in the South is conservative and evangelical ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:They share conservative and evangelical support in the South.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Next , a member of his audience , attired in a garment resembling the flag , attacked him ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:The word "attack" is used non-metaphorically because it describes a physical assault on someone.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “-- The other day , U.S. helicopters fired on Iranian gunboats that were preparing to attack a Panamanian ship near Farsi Island ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:To describe a physical military action taken against Iranian gunboats.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “The Sandinistas have now offered reasons for attacking and arresting anti - government demonstrators Sunday -LRB- '' Somocista Bands Invade Nandaime '' -RRB- ; for closing Radio Catolica -LRB- '' lack of respect for constitutional order '' -RRB- ; for arresting a Conservative Party leader -LRB- '' the principal instigator '' -RRB- ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:to maintain control and stability, to prevent threats to government authority and order.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “His antics once provoked an elderly ruling - party legislator to attack him with a cane ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:The legislator physically assaulted him with a cane in response to his actions.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Here in Masaya , supporters of a group known as the Mothers of Political Prisoners were brutally attacked by turbas in a well - documented incident in March ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:The attack was a physical assault carried out by a violent group against peaceful protestors.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “None of the Democratic leadership in the House or Senate was notified about the move , unlike when the U.S. ordered troops into Grenada in 1983 or last October when U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf attacked an oil platform that had been converted to a military facility ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Rapid decision-making, operational security, strategic advantage, minimizing leaks, swift response to threat.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Iran said its jets bombarded an Iraqi military base and oil refinery in Baghdad , and Iraq said its forces attacked 10 Iranian towns ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:Tensions, retaliation, border disputes, military conflicts, territorial claims, political agendas, strategic objectives, historical grievances.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Packages of '' fight material '' attacking Mr. Icahn are almost ready to be mailed to shareholders ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:The packages contain information or actions intended to harm or undermine Mr. Icahn's reputation or interests.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “They have agreed to attack only the Socalists , not each other , so Mr. Barre must find a way to beat Mr. Chirac without talking about him ”?
Usage:literal
Reason:To maintain a united front and focus on their common enemy, the Socialists.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “It turned out that a protein segment in cartilage is similar to the bacterial protein segment , which explained why the white cells also attacked the cartilage ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:The immune system mistook the cartilage for bacteria due to their similar protein segments.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “Mr. Schnittke is also a composer of extremes , and in the new Fourth Piano Sonata he has Mr. Feltsman achieving kinetic climaxes at the highest and lowest registers simultaneously , the pianist 's arms widely extended and lunging at the piano like a hawk attacking his prey ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:To convey the intensity and power of the music and the pianist's performance.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “'' A Bright Shining Lie '' will be attacked by those who have trimmed their judgments to this decade 's prevailing winds ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:Critics may disagree with the book's perspective or historical accuracy.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “I have dined out long enough on the strength of being attacked from the left by The Wall Street Journal editorial staff -LRB- it long being thought that nothing could exist to the right of that august body -RRB- ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:It implies criticism or opposition from a respected source.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “The dissident group plans to attack several provisions that block claimants ' ability to seek compensation from any source other than the special trust fund ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:Because they are trying to challenge or challenge the restrictions and limitations of the provisions.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “During the debate , when Mr. Chirac derided Mr. Mitterrand for having changed his mind from time to time during a 40-year political career , Mr. Mitterrand , clearly well coached , retorted with some 10-year - old quotations from Mr. Chirac attacking the European Community , which Mr. Chirac now warmly embraces ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:To show inconsistency and hypocrisy.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “The approach is raising eyebrows in the cigarette industry , which generally refrains from attacking the competition by name ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:Maintaining professionalism and avoiding legal issues.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “In addition , Mr. Joseph said , referring to the subcommittee 's questions about Beatrice , Texstyrene and one other junk - bond issue , by Hanover Petroleum Corp . , '' I do n't think it 's fair at all to attack the firm over two or three instances . '”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:Unfair to judge entire firm based on limited instances.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “If so , human cells may also make similar proteins -- potentially confusing immune cells that target foreign stress proteins and inducing them to attack a person 's own cells ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:Immune cells mistake the person's own cells for foreign stress proteins due to similarity.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “The virus attacked Argonne National Laboratory outside Chicago starting at 11:54 p.m. EST Wednesday and throughout the night ”?
Usage:metaphor
Reason:Personification of virus as an enemy, implying aggression and harm towards the laboratory.

Is “attack” used metaphorically in “In his own opinion , Chairman Ruder attacked both dissents as attempting to reduce the customer 's protection not only below the level set in the securities laws , but even below the standard set by common law ”?
